case_name: I G. Investment Trust v. Raja of Khalikote

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 850 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 850 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal against Orissa High Court judgment dated January 4, 1963 in Misc. Appeal No. 94 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated January 4, 1963 of the Orissa High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 94 of 1960.

facts.text: Predecessor-in-title of respondents executed three mortgages in favour of appellant company registered in London.

anchor.surface_text: The predecessor-in-title of the respondents had executed three mortgages in favour of the appellant- companypany, which is registered in London.

facts.text: First mortgage executed on October 23, 1903 securing £135,000, completely redeemed in 1935 according to both parties.

anchor.surface_text: The first mortgage was executed on October 23, 1903, securing a sum of pound 1,35,000/-. Inasmuch as, according to both parties, this mortgage has been companypletely redeemed in 1935,

facts.text: Second mortgage executed on December 18, 1906 for £77,500 borrowed by mortgagor.

anchor.surface_text: The second mortgage was executed on December 18, 1906, under which a sum of pound 77,500/- was borrowed by the mortgagor.

facts.text: Appellant admitted respondents paid £177,349 as interest on 1906 mortgage, more than twice the principal.

anchor.surface_text: Even according to the appellant, in respect of this mort- gage, the respondents had paid a total sum of pound 1,77,349/-, by way of interest which is more than twice the principal amount companyered by the mortgage.

facts.text: Third mortgage executed on October 21, 1935 for £65,000 borrowed by mortgagor.

anchor.surface_text: The third mortgage was executed on October 21. 1935, under which a sum of pound 65,0001- was borrowed by the mortgagor.

facts.text: Mortgagor repudiated 1906 mortgage claiming extinguished under s.10 Orissa Money-Lenders Act 1939 due to excess interest paid.

anchor.surface_text: the mortgagor, so far as the mortgage of 1906 was companycerned, repudiated the same on the ground that the entire transaction had been wiped off, by virtue of s. 10 of the Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939

facts.text: Appellant obtained ex parte decree in London for 1906 mortgage, not executable in India per Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: the companypany took legal proceedings in London and obtained an. ex parte decree. But attempts to execute the decree in India did number succeed, as will be seen from the decision of the Calcutta High Court

facts.text: Mortgaged properties vested in State of Orissa on June 1, 1953 under Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: the mortgaged properties vested in the State of Orissa, under the Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951  Act I of 1952   hereinafter called the Abolition Act , on June 1, 1953,

facts.text: Appellant filed claim petition before Claims Officer under s.18 of Abolition Act for dues under 1906 and 1935 mortgages.

anchor.surface_text: Inasmuch as the appellant had number realised the dues under the two later mortgages, they filed a claim petition before the Claims Officer, under s. 18 of the Abolition Act.

facts.text: Claims under 1935 mortgage substantially accepted by Claims Officer and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Though the claim included the third mortgage dated October 21, 1935, also, there does number appear to have been much of a serious companytest about the liability under that mortgage

facts.text: Appellant admitted receiving £177,349-18-0 as interest on 1906 mortgage and credited £29,000 to principal, balance £48,500 principal plus £17,460 interest up to May 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant has given credit to payment of a sum of pound 29,000/- towards the principal amount and, as such, a balance of E48,500/- remained due as principal. The appellant had claimed this amount, as well as the balance of interest payable, in the sum of E17,460/-, as being due upto May 1, 1953.

facts.text: Mortgagor contested claim before Claims Officer, pleading mortgage discharged under s.10 and s.17 of Money-Lenders Act.

anchor.surface_text: The mortgagor companytested the claim of the appellant before the Claims Officer. He pleaded that the claim of the mortgagee, under the mortgage, was numberlonger subsisting and that the mortgage liability had been discharged by payments and by operation of law.

facts.text: Claims Officer held 1906 mortgage extinguished under s.17 Money-Lenders Act (possessory for 15 years), rejected s.10/11 as not applicable to claims.

anchor.surface_text: The Claims Officer accepted the plea of the mortgagor that the mortgage of December 18, 1906, is a possessory mortgage and the mortgagees were in possession and enjoyment of the properties for 15 years from the date of the mortgage. In companysequence, the Claims Officer held that, in terms of S. 17 of the Money-Lenders Act, the mortgage of 1906 should be deemed to have been extinguished

facts.text: Both parties appealed to Board (Orissa High Court) under s.21 Abolition Act.

anchor.surface_text: Both the appellant and the respondents, had filed appeals under s. 21 of the Abolition Act to the Board, which, in this case, was the High Court,

facts.text: Board (Orissa HC) held on January 4, 1963 that 1906 mortgage not extinguished under s.17 but under ss.10/11 Money-Lenders Act, no amount payable.

anchor.surface_text: the Board has held that the view of the Claims Officer, that it has been extinguished, in view of S. 17 of the MoneyLenders Act, is number companyrect. ... the Board, ultimately, held that inasmuch as, even according to the appellant, the mortgagee had paid a sum of pound 1,77,349/-, the entire balance of principal and interest claimed by the mortgagee should be companysidered to have been fully paid.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal on certificate against Orissa HC judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, on certificate, is directed against the judgment of the Orissa High Court, dated January 4, 1963,

facts.text: Mortgagor repudiated liability by letter dated September 14, 1947 relying on Money-Lenders Act.

anchor.surface_text: the mortgagor, when a demand was made for payment of the amount by the mortgagee, has, by his letter dated September 14, 1947, repudiated his liability, relying on these provisions of the Money-Lenders Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld Board's decision that no amount due under 1906 mortgage under ss.10/11 Money-Lenders Act.

anchor.surface_text: the companyclusion arrived at by the Board, that the mortgage liability has been extinguished, is companyrect.

facts.text: Interest rate under 1906 mortgage was 6% per annum.

anchor.surface_text: The rate of interest payable under the mortgage was 6 per annum.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court decision: I G. Investment Trust v. Raja of Khalikote, AIR 1952 Cal 508 held London decree not executable.

anchor.surface_text: as will be seen from the decision of the Calcutta High Court in I G. Investment Trust v. Raja of Khalikote 1 . The High Court held that the decree obtained by the appellant in London was number executable in India.

facts.text: 1906 mortgage is possessory mortgage as held by Claims Officer.

anchor.surface_text: the Claims Officer accepted the plea of the mortgagor that the mortgage of December 18, 1906, is a possessory mortgage

facts.text: Board found mortgagee not in possession for 15 years under s.17, mortgagor was in possession.

anchor.surface_text: the Board has, after a companysideration of the evidence on record, companye to the companyclusion that the mortgagee has number been in possession for the requisite period referred to in s. 17 and that, on the other hand, the mortgagor himself had been in possession.

facts.text: Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939 (Act III of 1939) enacted to regulate money-lending and grant relief to debtors.

anchor.surface_text: The Money-Lenders Act has been enacted in 1939 and the preamble says that it was found expedient, by the Legislature, to regulate money-lending transactions and to grant relief to debtors in the State of Orissa.

by virtue of s. 10 of the Orissa Money-Lenders Act, 1939  Orissa Act III of 1939   hereinafter called the Money- Lenders Act , inasmuch as he had paid more than double the original principal amount, as admitted by the mortgagee.

arguments.claim: No amount due under 1906 mortgage as interest paid exceeds principal per ss.10/11 Money-Lenders Act

anchor.surface_text: the companyclusion arrived at by the Board, that the mortgage liability has been extinguished, is companyrect.

holdings.text: The conclusion arrived at by the Board, that the mortgage liability has been extinguished [under ss.10 and 11 of the Money-Lenders Act], is correct.

anchor.surface_text: Though we are not inclined to accept the reasons given by the Board for applying the provisions of ss. 10 and 11 of the MoneyLenders Act, we are, nevertheless, in agreement with the views expressed by the Board that those provisions can be applied- If so, the conclusion arrived at by the Board, that the mortgage liability has been extinguished, is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted interest payments of £177,349 exceed principal of £77,500; s.10(2) requires excess interest appropriated to principal, extinguishing entire liability as no balance remains.

holdings.text: The provisions of ss. 10 and 11 of the Money-Lenders Act can be applied [by the Claims Officer under s.20(1) of the Abolition Act to determine principal legally and justly due].

anchor.surface_text: Though we are not inclined to accept the reasons given by the Board for applying the provisions of ss. 10 and 11 of the MoneyLenders Act, we are, nevertheless, in agreement with the views expressed by the Board that those provisions can be applied- If so, the conclusion arrived at by the Board, that the mortgage liability has been extinguished, is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Legally and justly due' under s.20(1) requires Claims Officer to verify enforceability as a court would, applying other statutes like Money-Lenders Act to check legal impediments despite no explicit reference.

holdings.text: Claims Officer must consider pleas of discharge or limitation etc. even if not provided in clauses (a) to (f) of s.20(2) of the Abolition Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.20(1) imposes initial duty to ascertain if principal due and recoverable before applying s.20(2) calculation rules; restricting to s.20(2) would absurdly ignore subsistence of claim, discharge, or bar by law.

holdings.text: The Board is correct [that the provisions of the Money-Lenders Act can be taken into account by the Claims Officer under s.20(1) of the Abolition Act].
holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirms applicability post-analysis of 'legally and justly due'; integrates prior reasoning on impediments and judicial equivalence.

anchor.surface_text: Though we are not inclined to accept the reasons given by the Board for applying the provisions of ss. 10 and 11 of the MoneyLenders Act, we are, nevertheless, in agreement with the views expressed by the Board that those provisions can be applied- If so, the conclusion arrived at by the Board, that the mortgage liability has been extinguished, is correct.
The result is that the appeal fails and is dismissed.
